timeline.headline: History of the server-side web technology

date.headline: Web 1.0
date.text: This time was only static HTML pages served by web server

date.headline: Common Gateway Interface 1.0
date.text: CGI is a way (protocol) to let a website run scripts (usually Perl scripts back then) on the web server and display the output. Active version 1.1

date.headline: Hypertext Preprocessor 2
date.text: PHP aka Personal Home Page Tools is a general purpose scripting language, interpreter used as a CGI-program, written in C. Active version 7.3

date.headline: Active Server Pages 1.0
date.text: ASP later known as Classic ASP or ASP Classic, is Microsoft's first server-side script engine for dynamically generated web pages. Last version 3.0 in 2000

date.headline: Java Servlet 1.0
date.text: Java servlet is a Java software component that extends the capabilities of a server. It can respond to any types of requests. Lightweight Java threads instead of heavyweight OS processes. Active version 4.0

date.headline: Java Server Pages 1.0
date.text: JSP create dynamically generated web pages based on HTML, XML, or other document types. Active version 2.3

date.headline: ASP.NET 1.0
date.text: .NET is an open-source server-side web application framework designed for web development to produce dynamic web pages, written in .NET. Active version 4.7

date.headline: Ruby on Rails 1.0
date.text: Rails is a (MVC) framework, written in Ruby. Active version 5.2

date.headline: Django 1.0
date.text: Django is a free and open-source web framework, written in Python, which follows the model-view-template (MVT) architectural pattern. Active version 2.1

date.headline: Nodejs 1.0
date.text: is an open-source, cross-platform JavaScript run-time environment that executes JavaScript code outside of a browser at server-side. Active version 10.11
